text: I'll go through some basic ground rules.
speaker: MR. ARCHINACO

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The court reporter is the official transcript.  She takes down what we say, so think of it almost as a, I'll ask a question, then there is a potential of an objection.  Normally, you can answer after the objection, unless you have been instructed not to.  So it's question, potential objection, and then answer. If you give opposing counsel, Mr. Wiencek, an opportunity to state any objection, it will give you an opportunity also to think about your answer. Also, shakes and nods of the head don't work, so you have to keep your answers audible.  If for some reason you don't hear or understand a question, tell me you didn't hear or understand it.  Otherwise, I'll proceed as if you did. There is something called the attorney-client privilege.  I'm not seeking your conversations with counsel today, in terms of your conversations with Mr. Wiencek and things of that nature.  If any topics come up about where attorneys might have been involved in conversation, just proceed with caution.  You may be instructed not to answer questions at a certain point, depending upon what the questions are, so I'm trying to get your independent information.
speaker: MR. ARCHINACO

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Outside of attorneys.  Although, there may have been, at some points in the timeline --
speaker: MR. ARCHINACO

text: Yeah, an attorney involved.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Correct.  Okay.  So in those areas, just proceed with a little bit more caution in terms of how you're going to answer a question, just because the intent is not to get a waiver of some attorney-client privilege, but I may ask some questions around that. Anything -- is that all fair to you, what I have explained so far?
speaker: MR. ARCHINACO

text: Seems all reasonable, until something specific comes up, I guess.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  All right.  And then, generally, you can take a break whenever you want, unless a question is pending.  We try to do it about every hour or so, but if you need a break before then for any reason, just tell me, and we can go off the record, and we'll take a break.  Sometimes we'll go a little bit longer than an hour.

text: Okay.

speaker: MR. ARCHINACO

text: Sure.  So from -- in '93 and part of '94, I worked at Lake Hospital.  That's where I was a -- I did my -- our program had a, essentially an administrative internship or residency.  I did mine there at Lake Hospital outside of Cleveland.  And I ended up staying on there for a period of time, in what essentially I would call an assistant administrator role. And then from there, I took a job as a consultant.  That job might have gone to '95, now that I think about.  Took a job as a consultant and worked at a place called New Health Management.  And didn't really like consulting all that much, so I got reconnected with a person that I knew while I was at Lake. He was at Catholic Healthcare Partners at that time, so I came to -- he offered me a job in essentially kind of a new startup that they were working around, on doing around physician integration, employment, variety of different things, which was kind of, all kind of new at that time.  Health systems weren't widely involved with employing doctors.  So I took that job in the summer of '96.  And some of the dates may not be accurate here, but was in that for maybe three years. And health systems kind of got out of the business of employing doctors, for a variety of different reasons, so the need for that role kind of changed.  I ended up kind of changing jobs and going into more informatics, data collection, data analysis at the corporate offices of Catholic Healthcare Partners. And in 2003, from that job, I left the corporate office to take an operations job at Mercy Hospital-Clermont.  Had that job until the summer of '11, which is when I took this job.
